First time you drive in the rain, you're gonna be screwed. High voltage DC batteries in screwed together aluminum boxes. You've already seen what a small amount of coolant can do to one battery pack. I'm just curious about how the coolant pipes cool down the batteries?
Cause in a computer or car, the the pipe coming out of the hot end (out of the battery in your case) goes into a radiator (usually with a fan attached) which then dissipates the heat, then goes back to the reservoir. But in your case, the pump is just moving the heat right back into the batteries. I'm just worried for your batteries dude!

If you are going to run the coolant pump, keep the pump level with the coolant pipes or above. With hydrodynamics, you will want to mount your reservoir above the pump so the pump will require less energy to pull from it. It will have less of an energy load on the coolant pump motor and will be more efficient.

For the love of @#%!@% please make sure to run coolant through all those batteries *and* flush all bubbles *and* make sure you have a backup pump for the coolant. There is no fire worse than a telsa battery pack turning into an inferno.

I initially used the same green coolant but ran into some literature references that caste shade on it. I went to the ASTM Standards website. Green is acidic-not good for aluminum. Red is phosphatic - not good for aluminum. Pink or blue is pH neutral recommended for aluminum which is what our cooling modules use for internal channels. Obviously the same applies to the chill plate.under your inverter. I flushed my coolant with distilled water and am now running Xerex Asian Vehicle. Itâ€™s pink. I liked the green Gatorade in the D5 pump but looks arenâ€™t everything. The ASTM standards are ASTM 3306 and K2234. I donâ€™t know how critical it is for relatively low temperature operations but ....

Be very careful because you've never seen an explosion quite like a shorted lithium battery pack. It can vaporize a metal wrench almost instantaneously.
@Harry Goodman a small puncture over a high bump or something to a battery his entire thing is gonna get vaporised and burns for days
@Harry Goodman no he won't. There's no protection or proper structure to it.

@Harry Goodman Or the cheapo cooling pipe could get damaged or fall off the barbs and damage packs that way. I'd have used some automotive-grade pipe. It looked like there were loose BMS wires inside the boxes which will be fine for a while, but if there is too much movement then there could be abrasion and a short eventually. It feels like there is a shortage of failsafes in this design, but he's not gone into much detail so it's a little hard to tell. I'd have put some more isolation in, and indeed some insulation to make it easier to keep a good battery temperature.
The tesla packs do have a transparent insulating layer and he did insulate the busbars, so bashing the bottom won't necessarily short things, but it could. Maybe he's going to put a guard-plate underneath to make it more robust, especially at the front edge. It'll 'probably' be OK, but like I say, shortage of failsafes so it might end badly.
